utterances: We proved that American politics still is in the hands of ordinary folks like you and across this country who believes that it wasn't about who raised the most money, but who raise the greatest hopes.
That's former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee speaking last night after his Republican victory in Iowa.
Joining us now, the chairman of the Republican Party in New Hampshire.
He is Fergus Cullen.
He is with us from Concord.
Fergus Cullen, what do you make of the results in Iowa?
And how is that going to affect things in New Hampshire?
Well, certainly Mike Huckabee's win on the Republican side gives him a huge push of media.
And he's really lived off of earned media, freeing media coverage in New Hampshire to this point.
In fact, that's really what his campaign has been mostly about here to this point.
He's put more effort into Iowa than he has into New Hampshire.
That's not a knock on Governor Huckabee.
Certainly he's been leaving audiences with a favorable impression everywhere he's gone when he's been here.
But there's also no question his organization is not as strong in New Hampshire as that of many of the other candidates.
I actually also think what happened to the Democratic caucus matters in the New Hampshire Republican primary in this way.
I think that Obama's win increases the likelihood of an independent voter pulling a Democratic ballot here.
That could be harmful to John McCain, who certainly has been hoping to appeal to independents here as part of his push along with Republicans.
How many people do you know in the state - how many important political people do you know who are working for Governor Huckabee?
Well, it's about a dozen, I would say.
A dozen?
A dozen in the state?
And the people he has are very high quality people.
And here's why.

If you signed up with Governor Huckabee six months ago, it is because you are convinced that you like him and that he was somebody that you wanted to support not because you thought he was going to win.
So they really are conviction supporters.
And those are always great people to have.
No one signed up with Governor Huckabee six months ago because he was the frontrunner or they thought he was going to win.
So the people he has are of very high quality.
The challenge for him is that they're relatively few in number.
As you look at the state today, the analysis that I have seen from the vote in Iowa says that Governor Huckabee won because he got a lot of evangelicals.
That's not such a factor in New Hampshire, is it?
People weren't scrupulously following the law.
If you think that a physician is impaired or should not be practicing for a variety of reasons, there are certain actors who are supposed to report that to a certain entity.
So balls were dropped all along the way.
Ammons made 68 recommendations, many of which made it into legislation that passed unanimously in both houses.
Okay.
So Governor Roemer, your response?
Well, discussion of it in China's state media is pretty heavily censored at the moment.
But it's clear that people are worried because it runs counter to the trend of the past 40 years or so, which is basically China's reform era.
And during that time, the problem of political succession has been seen as China's sort of Achilles heel.
And leaders have tried to make the succession more institutionalized, more orderly and predictable.
And term limits are a part of that.
And so rolling this back really raises the specter of succession struggles and political instability.
That's NPR's Beijing correspondent Anthony Kuhn.
Thanks so much.
You're welcome.
Just three weeks after getting a shellacking in the midterm elections, yesterday President Obama got a fat lip.
The president played basketball Friday with some friends in the gym of the Fort McNair Army Base and reportedly took an elbow in the mouth from an opposing player who went up for a shot.
It took 12 stitches to close the First Fat Lip, if you please.

I'm not sure that Joe Frazier needed 12 stitches after the Thriller in Manila, though the White House stressed that a smaller filament was used, which increases the number of stitches but leaves a smaller scar.
I wonder if having a larger scar wouldn't actually fortify President Obama's profile as he contends with Kim Jong-Il, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad or Vladimir Putin.

Imagine a president with a gnarly vivid scar telling the rulers of China: Nice country you got here, I'd hate something to happen to it if you didn't stop fooling around with the value of your currency, know what I mean?
As recent presidential injuries go, President Obama's is almost valiant.
His immediate predecessor, President George W.
Bush, famously choked on a pretzel.
President Bill Clinton tore a tendon stumbling on the steps of Greg Norman's house after a round of golf.
But an elbow in the chops is a battle ribbon in basketball.
Mediocre players don't have to worry about their dental work.
An elbow is given to aggressive players who swing their own sharp limbs to grab a ball or push off a defender.
Well, the White House stressed yesterday that the president was elbowed inadvertently.
For hours yesterday, the White House didn't reveal the identity of the president's encored assailant, but in the absence of information, speculation abounded.

Among the hoopsters reportedly playing with President Obama were his nephew, Avery Robinson, a high school basketball star in Providence, Rhode Island; Reggie Love, the president's personal assistant, who played for Duke University's national championship team in 2001; and Education Secretary Arne Duncan, who played four years of pro basketball in Australia.

John Boehner was nowhere nearby, although it's tempting to recall that when Sarah Palin played point guard for the Wasilla High team that won an Alaska state championship, her nickname was Sarah Barracuda.
Last night, the White House finally released the name of the player whose elbow collided with the president's mouth: Reynaldo Decerega, who works for the Congressional Hispanic Institute.

The White House issued a statement from Mr. Decerega, calling the president a good sport and tough competitor and said he'll be back on the court soon - maybe after Mr. Decerega completes his White House tour of all the nuclear waste sites in Kazakhstan.
(Soundbite of choral music)
Sasha Baron Cohen and Aaron Cohen with their version of the anthem.
You're listening to NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY, I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Chadwick.
There's a new English translation of a book that's caused a lot of stir in Europe.
It's The Caged Virgin, a collection of essays from Dutch Parliamentarian Ayaan Hirsi Ali.
She calls it an emancipation proclamation for women in Islam.
She is a controversial figure among many of her fellow Muslims.
She's a native of Somalia who immigrated to the Netherlands about a dozen years ago.
Living in the West, Hirsi Ali felt free to publicly criticize Islam.
Well, that all changed in 2004.
That year her short film about the mistreatment of women in Islam was shown on Dutch television.
Her Dutch co-writer and director, Theo Van Gogh, was later stabbed to death by a Muslim radical.
A letter attached to his body threatened her life.
Since then she has lived with guards.
We spoke earlier about her book and what led to it.
Ayaan Hirsi Ali, the title of your book is The Caged Virgin.
Explain that, please.
Would you?
When I say the caged virgin, I mean the way women are treated, or the woman is treated in Islam.
Confining her to a lifetime of house arrest and taking away her freedoms results in being caged.
And because she's not only a wife or a sister or a niece, but she is also a mother, when she bares children, boys, she then gets the chance to bring them up.

But if she's ignorant, if she has been confined, if she's been denied her rights, she can only pass that on, the humiliation and the ignorance in which she lives, thereby putting not only herself but the whole of society in a cage.
You write that Muslim's have adopted the technological innovations of the West without its courage to think independently, and the most important explanation for that is the sexual morality of Islam.
Yes, and especially the emphasis on virginity.
And Judaic and Christian Theology stresses and emphasizes virginity as well, but in Islam it's not only taught, it's also enforced.

Women have to stay inside their homes, they have to wait until their parents decide who they are going to marry, and if a woman loses her virginity before she's married, then she's shunned or she's killed.
And that kind of morality brings about an abuse of such huge magnitude.

And if you have a society where women and homosexuals are repressed, then you have a society that lags behind, that has taken on the material side of modernity, like buying cars and computers and, you know, using all the gadgets that are a product of modernity, but that society has not come to terms with the values that modernity demands.
And the most important value is that the human individual is free.
You write about the fear in Western societies about confronting Islam.

You write about, for instance, the reaction to these Danish cartoons that were published last fall, the outrage in the Islamic world and a, perhaps movement is too strong a word, but a sense in some western democracies that you should limit press freedom in some way.
Is that a proposal before your own parliament?
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: But I'm the decider.
It's not.
Certainly, there are many evangelical conservatives in New Hampshire and they are a key part of our winning coalition here.
But even evangelicals in New Hampshire are Yankees first.
They may be evangelical, but they're not likely to be proselytizing or wearing their faith on their sleeve.
And to his credit, when Governor Huckabee's been in New Hampshire, he doesn't lead with faith.
He doesn't hide it or anything like that.
But that's not core to the message that he talks about on the stump the way it appears to have been in Iowa.
How about Governor Romney?
He finished second in Iowa after spending a lot of time and an enormous amount of money.
What are his prospects now?
I see that Senator McCain is rising in the polls.
Senator McCain has been on the rise in New Hampshire, but it's been due to a combination of factors.
Number one, McCain's been here a lot and he's been working his butt off.
Unlike other candidates who've had to share their time between New Hampshire and other states, McCain's been here basically full time for a month.
But Romney's support here is very solid.
They've run a great campaign all year long.

Their campaign strategy has been based on the assumption that unlike 2000, the 2008 Republican primary would be dominated by registered Republicans and not be characterized by a huge influx of independents.
Everything Romney has done has been aimed at the core heart of the Republican base, and they've done a really good job reaching that voter this whole campaign.
Each of these campaigns is distinct; each has a candidate.
But is there a message that you hear coming out of Iowa that is the right message now for Republicans?
Well, I think one key factor about the 2008 elections is that both Republicans and Democrats are going to be talking about change.
This is different from, say, 1988 when George Bush was saying I'm loyal to President Reagan, but I'm my own guy.
Or 2000 when Al Gore was a candidate saying I'm loyal to Bill Clinton, but I'm my own guy.
In this case, both the Republicans and Democrats are going to be talking about change.
And that seems to be what's resonating with the electorate.
Where are you going today?
Who's calling you up?
Who are you going to be walking around with?

I have tried over the last 12 months to see as many of the major candidates as frequently as I can, especially going to town hall meetings, or most typically I'll just take a seat in the back or stand against the wall and just observe.

And you know, the candidates who are doing the best in New Hampshire are those who have been running the most traditional campaigns here, characterized by lots of in-person candidate visits and lots of town hall meetings that are free and open to the public.
And those two candidates would be McCain and Romney.
Fergus Cullen is chair of the state Republican Party in New Hampshire, speaking with us from Concord, New Hampshire.
Fergus, thank you and get some rest.
The next days are going to be busy.
Thank you very much, Alex.
Republicans in Congress are reacting to President Trump's extraordinary statement on the U.S.
relationship with Saudi Arabia.
It was in response to the CIA's assessment that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman approved the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
Yesterday the president signaled he would not take strong action against Saudi Arabia or the crown prince.
And some Republicans say that sends a dangerous message to autocrats.

Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Bob Corker tweeted he never thought he would see a day that the White House would moonlight as a public relations firm for the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
It was as if they were writing a press release for Saudi Arabia and not for the United States.
And it was unnecessarily provocative.
Another Republican, Senator Lindsey Graham - usually a strong ally of President Trump - was also critical of the president's response, speaking here on FOX News.
